Team 2022 Team 2021
Caitlin Smallwood
“Growth is always essential. Running any tech company, you want to make sure you’re growing. Putting in place all of the right structure to be able to ensure growth.”
Being the Vice President of data science and analytics at Netflix, Smallwood is responsible for leading a team that works in the realm of predictive decision models, algorithm research, and experimentation science. Caitlin holds an M.S. in Operations Research from Stanford University and a B.S. in Mathematics from The College of William and Mary.
After working at Intuit, Yahoo!, and several consulting firms (PwC, SRA) and gaining experience in analytic disciplines and products, she joined Netflix in 2010 and revolutionized it. Caitlin is passionate about providing value to people through data. Hence, she has worked towards personalizing and creating mechanisms using Data Science, Machine Learning that is critical to the success of Netflix’s platform for recommending content to users.
Annie Sinha Roy
“Growth is always essential. Running any tech company, you want to make sure you’re growing. Putting in place all of the right structure to be able to ensure growth.”
Annie is the first woman to step foot into a territory where only men have worked till now. She is the first woman Tunnel engineer in India. After studying Mechanical Engineering at Nagpur University, she wanted to pursue a master's but had to take up a job to help with her family’s financial crunch after the demise of her father.
In 2015, she started working with Bangalore Metro Rail Corporation (BMRC) as an assistant manager. In BMRC, Annie single-handedly steered Godavari – the tunnel-boring machine that finished carving out the underground track from Sampige Road to Majestic. This helped with developing the 4.8 km east-west underground track of Namma Bangalore – the country’s first underground metro line in southern India. Her contribution was monumental.
Susan Wojcicki
“Growth is always essential. Running any tech company, you want to make sure you’re growing. Putting in place all of the right structure to be able to ensure growth.”
Susan Wojcicki is the CEO of Alphabet subsidiary YouTube, which has 2 billion monthly users. She previously was the senior vice president in charge of marketing at YouTube’s parent company, Google Inc. Susan graduated with honors from Harvard University, holds a master’s in economics from UC Santa Cruz and an MBA from UC Los Angeles. In 2015, Susan was named to Time’s list of the 100 most influential people in the world.
Susan Wojcicki has called herself “the mom of Google” the Internet giant was born in her garage that she rented out to recent graduates Sergey Brin and Larry Page. Wojcicki joined as Google employee number 16 in 1999 and worked on everything from AdSense and Google Analytics to Google Books and Google Images. In 2006, she advocated for the $1.65 billion acquisition of YouTube, which she has run since 2014.
Whitney Wolfe Herd
“The power lunch is no longer just for men. We all deserve a seat at the table.”
Wolfe Herd was born in Salt Lake City, Utah. She attended Judge Memorial Catholic High School and Southern Methodist University, where she majored in international studies. At the age of 20, she started a business selling bamboo tote bags for societal benefits. She introduced "Tender Heart", a clothing line dedicated to raising awareness around human trafficking and fair trade.
In 2012, Wolfe Herd joined the development team for the dating app Tinder (previously MatchBox). Later, Wolfe resigned from Tinder in April 2014, moved to Texas, and founded Bumble, a female-focused dating app. Wolfe Herd was named one of Business Insider’s 30 Most Important Women Under 30 in Tech in 2014. In 2016, she was named as one of Elle’s Women in Tech. She was also named to Forbes 30 under 30 in 2017 and 2018. In 2020, Forbes listed Wolfe Herd at number 39 of the top 100 “America’s richest self-made women”.
Safra Catz
“Define success on your own terms, achieve it by your own rules, and build a life you’re proud to live.”
Catz was born in Holon, Israel. She earned a bachelor's degree from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in 1983 and a J.D. from the University of Pennsylvania Law School in 1986.
Catz joined Oracle Corporation in April 1999. Catz was also the company's CFO, serving in that role from November 2005 to September 2008, and from April 2011 to the present. In December 2019, Oracle stated that Catz would be the sole CEO.
In 2009, she was ranked by Forbes as the 16th most powerful businesswoman. In 2014, she was ranked 24th. Catz was a director of HSBC from 2008-to 2015. Catz is the highest-paid female CEO of any U.S. company as of April 2017. Catz was elected to the board of directors of The Walt Disney Company in December 2017.
Katie Bouman
"We're a melting pot of astronomers, physicists, mathematicians, and engineers, and that's what it took to achieve something once thought impossible."
Katie Bouman is an assistant professor in the Computing and Mathematical Sciences Department at CalTech University. The focus of her research is on using emerging computational methods to push the boundaries of interdisciplinary imaging.
In the spring of 2019, the world saw the first image of a black hole, through the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) collaboration. As a postdoctoral fellow at MIT, Dr. Bouman contributed to the project’s success through six years of work on mission-critical algorithms used to process massive amounts of data collected by EHT’s strategically-positioned network of eight international radio observatories. Dr. Bouman is an inspiration to people everywhere, especially women working in STEM. According to her, “a career in science means working with people around the world. It’s going to telescopes at 15,000 feet. It’s working toward making the first image of a black hole.”
Tessy Thomas
“Gender does not matter. You work as a scientist, not as a woman.”
Coined the Missile Woman of India, Tessy Thomas was born in 1963 in the pretty backwaters of Kerala. She grew up near Thumba Rocket Launching Station and says her fascination with rockets and missiles began then.
While pursuing her M. Tech in Guided Missiles, she designed the guidance scheme for long-range missile systems which is used in all Agni missiles. She also invented another ground-breaking technology – the Re-Entry Vehicle System RV. This technology helps the missile to re-enter the atmosphere with a thundering velocity under high temperatures. In the year 2006, Tessy Thomas and her team failed in launching the Agni - III Missile safely. Yet, just 10 months later, they were able to successfully re-launch the missile. Dr. Tessy Thomas is the recipient of many prestigious awards including the DRDO Agni Award for Excellence in Self-Reliance in 2001 and the DRDO Award for Path Breaking Research/Outstanding Technology Development in 2007.
Nandini Harinath
“If you’re doing mission operations you don’t need to watch a science-fiction movie, we see the excitement in our day-to-day lives.”
Nandini Harinath is one of the leading women scientists at ISRO’s (Indian Space Research Organization) Satellite Centre in Bengaluru. Nandini hails from an academic background. Her mother was a mathematics teacher and her father an engineer. Her first exposure to science was the popular Star Trek series. It later inspired her to become a space scientist.
ISRO was the first job Nandini applied for and she got through. She is widely recognized as the Mission Design Deputy Operations Director of Mars Orbit Mission (MOM) or the Mangalyaan Mission, which was successfully launched in 2013. Harinath was the Operations Director for Risat-1 which is India’s first radar imaging satellite. She is also the Mission System Leader of NISAR, a joint NASA-ISRO satellite being developed to be launched in 2023. Since her joining ISRO, she has worked on 14 missions over 20 years.
Aarti Ramakrishnan
“Technologies like AI and machine learning become disruptive only when you know how to apply them to a real-world problem. That’s the crux of it. Identifying the right tech, applying it to the business problem, and building a scalable solution is necessary.”
Aarti Ramakrishnan is the Co-Founder and COO of Crayon Data. She was named one of the Top 10 Most Impactful Women in Technology in 2020. After securing an MBA in Finance, Aarti joined HDFC Bank as a management trainee and later joined the bank’s credit cards division. This ignited Aarti’s interest in product management, marketing, and analytics. With her co-founders, Aarti started Crayon Data in 2012. In her present role, Aarti ensures that the company’s strategy is translated into tangible outputs and that the organization-wide systems support sustainable and scalable growth.
Aarti believes that a transformational leader needs to be an enabler and not an enforcer. Under her leadership, Crayon has impacted over 20 million customers while driving billions of dollars in revenue for its clients. The company was recognized as one of the most innovative big data and AI start-ups by global platforms such as Gartner, TIEcon, and OrangeFab.
Gitanjali Rao
“My goal has really shifted not only from creating my own devices to solve the world’s problems, but inspiring others to do the same as well. So I really want to put out that message: If I can do it, you can do it, and anyone can do it.”
Gitanjali Rao is an American inventor, author, scientist, engineer, and STEM promoter. Born in 2005, Rao is of Indian descent and currently attends STEM School Highlands Ranch in Colorado. She was first influenced by a science kit her uncle gave to her when she was 4 years old. When she was 10, Rao heard about the Flint water crisis, leading to her using App Inventor to develop a device called Tethys that could send water quality information via Bluetooth.
In 2017, Rao won the Discovery Education 3M Young Scientist Challenge and was awarded $25,000 for her invention, Tethys. Rao has also developed an app named "Kindly" that uses artificial intelligence to detect cyberbullying at an early stage. In 2020, Rao became the first person to receive Time magazine's Kid of the Year designation. She was also recognized on Forbes 30 Under 30 for her innovations.
